context_meta.title: Was Aaron Hernandez Gay? Documentary Explores Football Player's Rumored Sexual Past
context_meta.summary: The two-part Aaron Hernandez Uncovered, which aired on the Oxygen network on Saturday and Sunday, presented a number of people close to the former NFL star who revealed Hernandez was a gay man. In the film, Alyssa Anderson, Hernandez’s ex-girlfriend, recalled rumors about Hernandez being involved with another man back when they were attending the University of Florida. Anderson said Hernandez continuously denied the claims.

context_meta.author: rocky.j.mountain
context_meta.title: Popovich, Spurs find 'silver lining' amid playoff struggle
context_meta.summary: Quiet concern brews in the business and ticket offices of the San Antonio Spurs over the prospect of losing the revenue they'd come to expect like clockwork from advancing to 20 consecutive postseasons. Twenty-four starting lineups, 185 total games missed -- including 61 by star forward Kawhi Leonard -- yet not one player, coach or member of personnel has lost focus in the face of current circumstances. "It's been a frustrating season," Spurs coach Gregg Popovich said. Mounting losses and uncertainty about who will be on the court next to you on a given night -- not to mention not knowing when Leonard will return from a mysterious quad ailment -- could understandably fracture or at least stress relationships in a locker room; especially in an organization with such a long track record of success.

context_meta.title: Top-seeded Kansas to face No. 5 seed Clemson Friday night in Omaha
context_meta.summary: It's Kansas vs. Clemson on Friday night in Omaha, Neb., with a trip to the Elite Eight on the line. The top-seeded Jayhawks (29-7) will be playing for a third consecutive trip to the Elite Eight and the eighth in head coach Bill Self's 15 seasons at Kansas. The fifth-seeded Tigers (25-9), who thrashed No. 4 seed Auburn 84-53 on Sunday night in San Diego, will be playing for a spot in just their second Elite Eight in school history. Their only other trip came in 1980 and the Tigers are playing in just their 12th NCAA Tournament ever and first since 2011. context_meta.title: Isaiah Thomas on possible Boston Celtics return: 'Anything can happen'
context_meta.summary: In a surprising turn of events, Isaiah Thomas tweeted Sunday night that with regard to a Boston Celtics return, “Anything can happen.” Anything is possible. Those were the iconic words screamed from the mountaintop of an NBA title by Kevin Garnett on the Garden floor in 2008 after he helped lead the Boston Celtics to their 17th title. It turns out that's exactly what was running through Isaiah Thomas' mind when he was asked if he would consider coming back to Boston this offseason. It's a surprising response from Thomas, who was bitter after his departure. context_meta.title: Del Potro edges Federer in 3 sets to win Indian Wells title
context_meta.summary: The struggle paid off Sunday, when Del Potro staved off three match points in the third set to beat top-ranked Roger Federer 6-4,7-6 (8), 7-6 (2) for the BNP Paribas Open title. The win ranks up there with Del Potro's 2009 U.S. Open title, in which he beat Federer, and helping Argentina win the Davis Cup in 2016. ''I cannot believe I won this tournament, beating Roger in a great final and level of tennis,'' Del Potro said.

context_meta.title: On Shaka Smart and the question of Havoc at Texas
context_meta.summary: The question came and Shaka Smart lit up. In late November, the Texas Longhorns head coach was asked about playing his signature style of basketball that helped the VCU Rams reach the Final Four in 2011 — the fullcourt pressure, transition-oriented attack known as “Havoc.” “I love playing that way, man, you know that.” And yet, “Havoc” never came to Texas — VCU branded it as an official trademark in 2012 and shortly after Smart took the job in Austin, his new school abandoned an application to register “Horns Havoc” and “Havoc House.” More than just in branding terms, however, the style of play that helped define Smart at VCU, the only head coaching stop in his career, hasn't really showed up

context_meta.title: Cavs concerned about Tyronn Lue's illness
context_meta.summary: Tyronn Lue's absence is starting to cause concern. The Cavaliers survived Saturday's 114-109 win against the Bulls as their coach exited with an undisclosed illness for the third time this season, leaving associate head coach Larry Drew to take over. "I'm not sure exactly what it is," Drew said after the game, via ESPN. "I just know that before coming out in the second half, he wasn't feeling well. And I thought that there was a chance that he would (eventually) come out, but he just wasn't well enough to come out, so we had to just go on."
